reviewText:
I am really digging this game.

It kinda has an SNK fighting game feel to it, but there is a skill progression that really adds depth and playthrough time to the game.  As you progress further in your stats, you unlock new training minigames that really help keep them from feeling stale.

As for the controls, they're pretty tight for being an indie title.  However, the game assumes you have an Xbox 360 controller, as the on-screen button prompts are of the A+B+X+Y variety, makes it confusing if you're using a keyboard.  Personally, I'm using a USB-connected SNES controller and it works beautifully with this game.

The graphics really capture the feel of the transitional period between the 16-bit and 32-bit console eras (think NEO-GEO), and they are of much higher quality than your average indie fare.

The sound effects and music really make this game shine, once again perfectly capturing that bygone era that a lot of us spent middle school listening to as we played our games.

If I were to criticize anything, it would probably be the rough translation job, but it's a minor slight that doesn't take away from the game much at all.

The devs have some real talent, and this game is well worth the $10.  I'd like to see where they go from here.

Nineteen eighty five called, it would like to have a word with you about cheesy Karate games. Specifically, I would like you to cast your mind back to the spectrum era. Long loading times, terribad graphics, but a blank canvas where game creativity was about pushing boundaries and exploring what games could be. One of those many explorations was a title called IK+ (International Karate +), a glorious bit of code involving some pixellated men in pyjamas whacking each other in the goal of changing their belt colours. The controls were tight, the fighting was good, and the feeling was very much that of a cheesy b-movie. Hell, the Amiga version had Stephen Segal (or a very good likeness)[www.atarimania.com] on the cover along with what looks to be Chuck Norris delivering a trademark kick to some poor sod. Fighting games have wavered in and out of vogue, travelling between the more realistic and the more fantastical over the generations, but the pure, basic Karate game sortof vanished into the ether...

... UNTIL NOW...

... KAHATAE MASTAH. NOCKA DOON BALOO. OSU!

It's gloriously throwback, the graphics are retro Amiga era, the script has more chinglish than a motherboard manual, you get to Karate Fight a bull and a bear (yes, you get the opportunity to punch a bear), and you get to do a jump kick over a car to promote your dojo. It's that kind of finely matured cheese. Jackie Chan would be -proud- to feature in such a script. It has so much terribleness (like the fact you can exit without saving very easily and the game does a TERRIBLE job of warning you) that it has no right to be as good as it is. Yet, it is. It's good, it's good in the way finely matured cheese is good.

The game features a mix of tournaments, one shot fights against various opponents (who if you beat, will then appear in the said same tournaments), special encounters such as the aforementioned DO A FLYING KICK OVER A CAR!"

reviewText:
OSU!

In short; this game is a mixture of a classic arcade title like Karate Champs, IK+, or the obscure Chatan Yarakuu Shanku - The Karate Tournament, with Art of Fighting's visuals and the recent UFC titles' attention to detail, with a touch of RPG and simulation.

If you look at the screenshots and expect Karate Master 2: Knock Down Blow to be a typical Street Fighter II clone straight from the 90s you'll be in for a surprise.  In this game you play as forklift truck driver and karate novice Ken during his young adult years in 1980s Japan as he hones his skills, tempers his body and soul, breaks his bones, and fights every rival in order to achieve his goal of becoming a karate master and open his own school.

To accomplish this you will be tasked with taking on the various dojos of this harbour town, most of which are variations of karate, but you will also fight boxing, wrestling, Muay Thai, and Taikwondo practitioners, as well as the odd bull or car, and defeating their students to make a name for yourself.

However, these dojos don't except a new face.  You need to earn fame by winning two types of tournaments, one with protective gear and one without.  The difference supposedly is face hitting is against the rules of the latter tournament, however there isn't any in game punishment for this so just go wild.  I did find it the tougher tournament of the two, but otherwise they're very similar.

However, you will also need to earn money in order to enter these, and other tournaments, which is earned with a rather simple yet satisfying forklift minigame that brings back memories of the similarly themed Shenmue.

Winning the tournaments and defeating dojos will earn you training days, which are used to increase your Stength, Speed, Toughness, Ki (stamina), and Tai Kitae (described as increasing the roughness of your skin, effectively it increases your chance of critical blows) which are handled via various mini games that are unlocked as you progress in each stat.  Unfortunately a lot of these are rather hit and miss, but they're short enough that they likely won't be too off putting, but you will be playing them a lot.

As for the combat itself you have the d-pad and four face buttons, which for reference I will be using the X-Box pad layout for further descriptions.  Much like Tekken or UFC titles the face buttons represent Kens left and right punches and kicks, and the d-pad is used to aim for high, mid, or low strikes, combinations of the buttons are used for various techniques, and pressing the two punches together, plus a direction, will perform one of your defensive katas.

Instead of a health metre, your body, as well as your opponent's, is represented by a small green silhouette which indicates damage to your head, legs, arms, or torso by changing to light green, yellow, orange, and finally red.  This increases the chance of being knocked out, but fortunately does recover slightly.  I'm not certain what governs recovery as such, but you'll sometimes be very grateful for a Yame, where the fight pauses due to either one of the combatants falling to te mat or going out of bounds, after which the combatants return to their starting positions.  This gives you a moment for recovery of both your health and Ki, though be warns, if you've taken too much of a beating you won't heal at all.

Fights are tense at first, as a single strike can end a match due to the opponent being too strong, or them breaking your bones with a critical.  When this happens you end up in hospital and must engage in a mini game to heal.  Fortunately this action goes both ways, meaning you can score a luck strike as well.

The game feels both technical and arcadey, I don't want to say I had to use a lot of skill beyond targeting a certain area, and some fights can feel like they're just a war of attrition, but at the same time are very enjoyable.  Hitting a heavy blow or dazing an opponent by getting in a Brainshock or similar feels great, and having to back off and rethink your game due to getting pulverised in the first few seconds and make a very tense moment or two, leading to a more brutal feel than the more famous fighters out there.

The visuals and sound really help there, seeing a realistic amount of blood splattering the fighters and the floor, heay blows sounding like an explosion as the game momentarily shudders as the screen is framed with a red haze, and the aforementioned Brain/Livershock, being left breathless, or a receiving muscle injury causes a dizzying, wobbly effect as the fighter starts staggering as they try to fight, all of it leads to a real sense of risk and struggle.

The graphics aren't superb sadly, the sprite work, while effective, does look very rough, especially on some of the fighters, and some of the backgrounds are poorly rendered polygon work, though it has some of the better audiences I've seen in a game.  The music is pretty good, if not very memorable.  It has the feel of an old Tokusatsu show, as well as a classic beat 'em up, and fits the game very well.

Unfortunately the game does have some issues, occasionally the controls would become unresponsive, and the game can be rather repetitive, as grinding is necessary to max out your stats, and get enough money to get through the game.  It also hurts that there's a distinct lack of multiplayer, which would be great in a game this dedicated to an authentic feeling fighting game RPG.

I spent around 6 hours in order to get to the credits, which considering the price is very good.  I can honestly say I had a huge amount of fun in that time, and would love to play more.  Hopefully there will be a sequel some day, with multiplayer included.

reviewText:
I'm definitely positive about this one, but with a couple of reservations.

The first is, I was hoping for something that felt a lot more like Princess Maker or one of those games where you pick and develop a career. The second was, I was hoping for more meaningful specializations - developing an overpowered kick at the expense of punches, say. Neither of these elements, or anything like them, really, are in the game.

But what we do have is an absolute beauty of a retro-styled martial arts fighter with RPG elements. It is very, very grindy, but the fights and occasional training minigames are, for the most part, a fun way to blow through a few minutes here and there. The translation isn't quite right, which, honestly, adds to the flavour. It feels SO much like a game from the 90s or 80s it's insane.

If it's on special, this game is a no-brainer. If it's not, and you're willing to support devs, go for it.

reviewText:
If you are into full contact karate , get this right now! If you used to like Super Nes fighting games , get it now!

But the most important feature of this game that I believe a lot of people miss is the fact that it portraits some of the Kyokushin Karate Golden Era most important fighters! Those who lived or know the Kyokushin Karate history will definively love this game just for this feature.

The gameplay for a 2d fighting game is awesome - good timing and distance will get you the wins , not button mashing or insane combos ( this also capture the atmosphere of the 80's good fighting games ) Still on the karate side: the moves are realistic , the damage, the training sessions, everything is exaclty what it was like to be a karate fighter in the 80's. There is very little fantasy / unrealistic situations represented in this game.

If you have no ties to Karate at all , the game inevitably looses a lot of appeal, but I would still recommend it purely as a 2D fighting game.

Basically, this game is Garouden Break Blow in 2d if you could only pick Karate. Which is to say its a very competant, decently technical Karate 'sim' while being easy enough to pick up and play yet sufficiently challenging, The underlying mechanics are very solid and make for enjoyable technical battles where button mashing generally gets you killed.

The bad? Grind, and MAXIMUM WEEABOO. Come on guys, the over-usage of romanized Japanese in the game is totally utterly unnecessary, especially when you can't even spell 'strength' correctly. While in reality, Karate dojos do use all the Japanese terms used in this game while in training... its totally unnecessary in a game. Put all the terms in a Glossary and stop being such maximum weeaboo tryhard. The quality of the English used in dialog is of an exceptionally POOR quality as well.

That's the bad part.

Fortunately the game isn't about picking on a bunch of Italian developers' English skills (or lack thereof), its about being a very solid and fun Karate sim, which the game does deliver and deliver strongly. A bit more polish however would have sufficed, and 100% less weeaboo.

For a game like this, that really works better with a controller, this is a pretty serious issue, and one I hope gets addressed soon.

Oldschool fun, at least until the game refuses to load anymore.

I was having a blast with this game, it reminded me of games like Best of the Best and IK+ from way back in the day but wit the graphics of the classic SNK fighting game Art of Fighting. Then after two hours or so of play the game then refused to work. First I got a black screen with a couple of white boxes where you could hear the game music playing but could do nothing else except ALT/TAB out and close it. Then the game stopped operating at all. This is a very common problem and gathering by the Community posts I'm lucky I had the game run properly for as long as I did as some have been unable to run the game at all. I've tried every fix imaginable but this game is now dead and refusing to work at all and there is no developer support, the game has not been updated since last September.

This is another sad case of the appalling quality control that exists on Steam. If developers and publishers aren't going to commit to making their software work for their customers they should not be allowed to sell it on Steam. This issue will not go away until Steam finally starts caring about what goes on their store front. Very disappointing.
